title: Colonization, Early Institutions and the Origin of State Capacity and Democratization
descriptions:
The proposed project, "Colonization, Early Institutions and the Origin of State Capacity and Democratization," aims to investigate the relationship between the origin of state capacity, democracy, and political dynasties within the context of the colonial conquest of Latin America. The research will utilize a methodological approach that includes case studies, panel data analysis, country-fixed effects, and instrumental variables. 

One key advantage of this project is the focus on the initial years of colonization when conquerors lacked knowledge about the land, providing a unique opportunity to study the development of early institutions. The colonial power of Spain will be the primary focus, with data sourced from the Capitulaciones and Archivo de Indias. 

Specific information to be examined includes the rules governing early institutions and the location of initial settlements at the subnational level. By analyzing these factors, the project aims to shed light on how the process of colonization influenced the development of state capacity, democratization, and the prevalence of political dynasties in Latin America. 

The findings from this research have the potential to contribute significantly to our understanding of the historical roots of state capacity and democracy in the region. Ultimately, this project seeks to provide valuable insights that can inform current debates on governance, political development, and democratization processes in Latin America and beyond.
